Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Hi Bruce41! Welcome to The Forum! I agree with all 3 responses so far from Another, HighlanderCFH & SubDenis. However, the timing of action(s) will ultimately be determined by your URO MD. Questions & Suggestions: - Was the blood drawn for PSA taken before or after the DRE? - Wait for the results of the Select MDX test. Be sure that your MD fully understands and can explain these results. - If not already done, ask your URO MD about repeating the PSA test in about 8 weeks and to request a PSA test that measures both PSAfree and PSAbound fractions. - If & when biopsy is indicated, follow SubDenis' suggestion and ask about a "multiparametric MRI and fusion biopsy." There may be a problem with insurance reimbursement. The MRI can detect most areas of suspicion and the spacial locations programmed so that the TRUS biopsy can be "guided" to any hot spots. Try to relax and not panic. You have not been diagnosed with PCa. Even if this happens (hoping not!) you will likely be in a 100% curable category. Keep asking questions and seeking knowledge (exactly as you are doing) and keep us updated. MF WOW - I am really thankful for the responses I received from this Forum - thanks to all! I had no idea what a valuable resource this forum would be in such a short time!! Blood was drawn prior to DRE by a couple of weeks Also I do have BPH and frequent urination including two to three times per night but thank god I usually fall right back to sleep I ride a bicycle 7,000+ miles per year so 4 days a week on the bike and the other 3 days at the local LA Fitness facility for Core and Upper body work - so basically good physical condition at 66
Posts.Title: Considering first Prostate biopsy

Posts.Content: My previous Urologist sold his business in So Cal and I had my first visit to new Urologist yesterday She is a bit more aggressive then my previous Dr and recommended a prostate biopsy on first visit based on 3 factors: PSA results over the past 3 years 2.6, 3.5 and 3.2 Digital rectal exam revealed "OK mushy on left side and hard right side" of Prostrate Older brother had prostate cancer detected 4 years ago at age 70 (I am 66) - which resulted in surgical removal of prostate We talked about the decision and I decided on Select MDX urine test first - results due in two weeks Should I get a second opinion assuming the Select MDX results are not encouraging prior to committing to a biopsy ?
Posts.Title: Considering first Prostate biopsy

Posts.Title: Considering first Prostate biopsy

Posts.Content: Your responses were very helpful and you asked for an update....please see below: On the trusted advice of two Urologists and your responses I did undergo a multiparametric MRI - summary findings below: * Originally Posted by Michael F Hi Bruce41! Welcome to The Forum! I agree with all 3 responses so far from Another, HighlanderCFH & SubDenis. However, the timing of action(s) will ultimately be determined by your URO MD. Questions & Suggestions: - Was the blood drawn for PSA taken before or after the DRE? - Wait for the results of the Select MDX test. Be sure that your MD fully understands and can explain these results. - If not already done, ask your URO MD about repeating the PSA test in about 8 weeks and to request a PSA test that measures both PSAfree and PSAbound fractions. - If & when biopsy is indicated, follow SubDenis' suggestion and ask about a "multiparametric MRI and fusion biopsy." There may be a problem with insurance reimbursement. The MRI can detect most areas of suspicion and the spacial locations programmed so that the TRUS biopsy can be "guided" to any hot spots. Try to relax and not panic. You have not been diagnosed with PCa. Even if this happens (hoping not!) you will likely be in a 100% curable category. Keep asking questions and seeking knowledge (exactly as you are doing) and keep us updated. MF
Posts.Title: Considering first Prostate biopsy

Posts.Content: Your responses were very helpful and you asked for an update....please see below: On the trusted advice of two Urologists and your responses I did undergo a multiparametric MRI - summary findings below using their scale of 1-5 Two abnormalities found: 1) had a PI-RADS score of 3 2) had a PI-RADS score of 4 Seminal Vesicles - No Seminal Vesicle involvement Lymph Nodes - no evidence of pelvic lymphadenopathy Pelvis Bowl - Unremarkable Ascites - Trace pelvic ascites Pelvic Bones - No suspicious lesions in pelvis Based on the findings above I scheduled a fusion biopsy for this Friday 10/13/17 Assuming the biopsy is positive my leaning is towards Radical Prostatectomy since everything I read states this surgery yields the greatest probability for extending life span
